chapter.title: Editing continuous fields
chapter.para:
editorcontinuous surface The continuous field editor allows you to edit gridded fields in your depiction. Here are some examples of different continuous fields:
MSL pressure
surface temperature
wave height
sea temperature
maximum temperature
The continuous field editor controls appear when you choose to edit a continuous field. Continuous field edit tools

sect1.title: Moving a feature on a continuous field
sect1.para: continuous field editormove You can move a feature feature with a minimum of distortion occurring within an outlined area using the Move tool.

listitem.para:
Select the move tool.
Move
The move menus appear. (see ) Move menus
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Draw the boundary around the feature feature you want to move.
(see )
This becomes the area of minimum distortion.
Select a radius of influence. (see ) Radius of influence
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.

Note: Percentages range from 1 to 100 where 1 is the minimum radius of influence and 100 is approximately one quarter of the map area. Your System Administrator establishes the exact percentage increments.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius of influence while inside the map area.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Translate.
Pick a reference point inside the feature and hold the &left; mouse button down.

The reference point can be anywhere in the feature; however, if you are moving a portion of the feature off the depiction it is important to pick a point that will remain on the depiction after the move. The line shimmers indicating you can now move it.
Drag the feature to the new location.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.
Note: You can still restore the field if you click Undo at this point.

sect1.title: Rotating a feature on a continuous field
sect1.para: continuous field editorrotate You can rotate a feature feature with a minimum of distortion occurring within an outlined area using the Move tool.

listitem.para:
Select the move tool.
Move
The move menus appear. (see )
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Draw the boundary around the feature feature you want to move.
(see )
This becomes the area of minimum distortion.
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.

Note: Percentages range from 1 to 100 where 1 is the minimum radius of influence and 100 is approximately one quarter of the map area. Your System Administrator establishes the exact percentage increments.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius of influence while inside the map area.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Rotate.
Press the &left; mouse button at the point you want to rotate around (the centre of rotation).
Select a second point to form a handle to rotate the feature and hold the &left; mouse button down. This is your rotation handle (like the handle of a car window).
A line displays between the two chosen points.
The handle point can be anywhere; however, it is important to pick a point that will remain on the depiction after the rotate. The line shimmers indicating you can now rotate it.
Turn the handle to a new location.
When you have reached the point where the rotation should end, release the &left; mouse button.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.
Note: You can still restore the field if you click Undo at this point.

sect1.title: Copying a feature
sect1.para: continuous field editorcopy You can copy a feature feature by using Copy and Paste with the Move tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Move tool.
Move
The move menus appear. (see )
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Draw the boundary around the feature you want to copy.
(see )
This becomes the area of minimum distortion.
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Copy.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Cancel to cancel the current move action, or move to another depiction.
Paste is now available.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Paste.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Translate to enter translation mode (see steps 6-7) or Rotate to enter rotation mode (see steps 6-9).

sect1.title: Changing the value at a given point (Poke)
sect1.para: continuous field editorpoke The Poke tool allows you to pick a point on the depiction and change its value. The field within the radius of influence is altered to smooth the resulting field. In the case of pressure, you can change the pressure value at a given point by a delta amount to deepen a low or increase a high.

orderedlist.title: To change the value at a given point:

listitem.para:
Select the Poke tool.
Poke
The Poke menus appear. (see ) Continuous field edit poke menus
Move the slider on the slider-bar to adjust the delta amount. (see )
Positive values increase the value at the specified point by that value and negative values decrease the value by that amount. (If you select zero, nothing happens.)
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius of influence while inside the map area.
Pick the point on the depiction you want to change.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.

sect1.para: Remember to select your delta value first. If you forget and select the point to change first, the existing value is applied.

sect1.title: Changing the value in a given area (Stomp)
sect1.para: continuous field editorstomp The Stomp tool allows you to specify an area on the depiction and change all values within the area. This is similar to the Poke tool, but is like poking with an area rather than a point.

orderedlist.title: To change the value in a given area:

listitem.para:
Select the Stomp tool.
Stomp
The Stomp menus appear. (see ) Continuous field edit stomp menus

Draw the outline of the area to stomp on the depiction or click the &right; mouse button and select Boundary from and choose Use Last Stomp Outline or a preset outline if your System Administrator has configured some predefined outlines.
The boundary is shown on the depiction.
Move the slider on the slider-bar to adjust the delta amount. (see )
Positive values increase the value at the specified area by that value and negative values decrease the value by that amount. (If you select zero, nothing happens.)
Select the amount of taper to determine the shape of the Stomp area.

Note: The taper parameter allows you to change the shape of the field adjustment. A flat topped taper applies the same adjustment over the interior of the selected area. A curved taper applies a larger adjustment at the centre of the selected area, and smaller adjustments towards the edges.
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Proceed.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.

sect1.title: Dragging a feature on a continuous field
sect1.para: continuous field editordrag The Drag tool allows you to drag values of the continuous field to another position.

listitem.para:
Select the Drag tool.
Drag
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius of influence while inside the map area.
Pick the point you want to drag and hold the &left; mouse button down.
The point is shown with a blue box.
Drag the pointer to a new location and release.
A yellow line indicates the path of the drag and the end point.
Repeat the previous two steps for the remaining points to drag.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Proceed when you have finished picking points to drag.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.

sect2.title: Tightening a gradient
sect2.para: continuous field editortighten gradient The Drag tool can be used to tighten a gradient or to extend a trough or ridge. You can use radius of influence (see ) to control the area of effect of the edit tool.

listitem.para: Specify one set of drags that anchors one line by picking a point on the line and releasing the button in the same place.
Specify a second set of drags that moves the second line towards the first.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Proceed to indicate that you have completed the selection.
The gradients are tightened.
Note: The numerical solution to multiple drags is non-linear. Predicting the effect of multiple drags comes with experience.

sect1.title: Smoothing information on a continuous field

listitem.para:
Select the Smoothing tool.
Smooth
The Smoothing menus appear. (see ) Continuous/Vector field edit smooth menus
Select a portion of the surface to smooth.
(see )
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius while inside the map area.
Select a smoothing factor (a multiple of the current grid spacing)
Click the &right; mouse button and select Proceed.
The &FPA; recomputes the field and re-displays the new field contours in white. The original contours remain in the normal field colour.

sect1.title: Merging information in a continuous field
sect1.para: continuous field editormerge You can bring a field from another source and time and merge it into the depiction using the Merge tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Merge tool.
Merge
The Merge menus appear. (see ) Merge menus
Select the Source, Issue Time and Valid Time of the other field you wish to merge with your current depiction.
Note: Your System Administrator may configure a field to accept merges from another "compatible" field. If this is the case, there will be a Field list in the Merge Fields area.
Click Fetch.
The field information from the other source is laid over top of your depiction.
Select Include Labels if you want to include labels.
Draw the boundary of the area you want to adopt from the new source.
(see )
Select a radius of influence. (see )
The percentage indicates the affected area surrounding the point of edit.
The cursor appears with the chosen radius while inside the map area.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Merge to merge in place, Translate to enter translation mode (see steps 6-7), or Rotate to enter rotation mode (see steps 6-9).
The new field merges.

sect1.title: Labelling your depiction
sect1.para: continuous field editorlabel The Labelling tool allows you to label the field contours, maxima and minima and set label attributes. You can also delete labels.

listitem.para:
Select the Labelling tool.
Label
Click the &right; mouse button and select a Label Type.

Click the &right; mouse button and select a Label Action: &colwidth2;
Click...To...
Label ActionAdd add a label at a specified point
Label ActionMove facilitate clicking and dragging a label from one location to another (if applicable)
Label ActionModify change label attributes
Label ActionShow display a list of attributes of the particular label selected
Label ActionDelete delete a label
Note: some labels have fixed attributes and cannot be modified. In these cases the Modify tool does not appear.
Pick a point to label using the &left; mouse button.
If you have picked Add....
With automatic labelling, the label appears on the nearest contour or at the nearest high or low.
All other types of labels appear directly where you click.
Note: If your label type requires additional information, an entry menu may appear. You can modify the information as required. Clicking on Set Attributes will add the label.
If you have picked Move, Modify, Show or Delete ...
The nearest label is chosen.
To delete all the labels, click the &right; mouse button and select Clear.

sect1.title: Sampling values on a continuous field
sect1.para: continuous field editorsample You can add temporary labels to the &FPA; window with the Sample tool.

listitem.para:
Select the Sample tool.
Sample
The Sample menus appear. (see ) Sample menus
The cursor appears as cross-hairs while inside the map window.
Select the type of sample you want from the Sample Item area.
Select the display Attributes: colour, size and font.
Pick a point on the depiction.
A temporary label appears.
You can sample as many points as you want.
Click the &right; mouse button and select Clear to clear the samples from the depiction.
